By BA Rentals Team·Updated February 2026
South Buenos Aires
7/10

San Telmo

The soul of old Buenos Aires — cobblestone streets, tango bars, antique shops, and the legendary Sunday market. Authentic, bohemian, and more affordable than northern neighborhoods.

$700–$1,100
Monthly Rent
Moderate
Safety
Good
Transport
Very Good
Food Scene

Living in San Telmo

San Telmo is Buenos Aires at its most atmospheric. The neighborhood's cobblestone streets, crumbling colonial mansions, and corner tango bars transport you to another era. Every Sunday, the Feria de San Telmo transforms Calle Defensa into a mile-long market of antiques, crafts, and street performers — it's one of the most iconic experiences in the city.

Living in San Telmo means immersing yourself in authentic porteño culture. The cafes are old-school (Bar Sur, Café Dorrego), the buildings have character (exposed brick, iron balconies), and the neighbors are a mix of longtime residents, artists, and younger expats drawn by lower rents. The main drawback is safety — while the main streets (Defensa, Estados Unidos, Bolívar) are fine, some side streets can feel sketchy at night, especially south of Avenida Independencia.

The neighborhood is gentrifying but still has rough edges. Rents are significantly lower than Palermo or Recoleta, making it popular with artists, writers, and expats on tighter budgets. The Subte C and E lines provide connectivity, and the location near the city center (Microcentro) is actually more convenient than Palermo for some purposes.

What expats say about san telmo

“San Telmo has soul. The Sunday market, the tango in the streets, the old buildings with character. Yes, it's grittier than Palermo, but that's why I love it. Feels like real Buenos Aires.”

Ana

Artist · From Mexico

Key Facts
Founded1735 (oldest neighborhood)
Average Age28-45
CharacterBohemian / Historic
Sunday Market10 AM - 5 PM

Who Should Live Here?

Best For
  • Artists and creatives
  • Budget-conscious expats
  • History lovers
  • Tango enthusiasts
Not Ideal For
  • Safety-conscious families
  • Those wanting modern apartments
  • Night walkers on side streets

Highlights

  • Sunday market (Feria de San Telmo)
  • Authentic tango culture and milongas
  • Historic architecture and cobblestone streets
  • Most affordable central neighborhood
  • Art galleries and antique shops
  • Walking distance to city center

Considerations

  • Side streets can be unsafe at night
  • Older buildings with potential maintenance issues
  • Tourist-targeted scams near the market
  • Less modern infrastructure
  • Flooding risk on some blocks

Notable Landmarks

Feria de San TelmoPlaza DorregoMercado de San TelmoEl Zanjón de GranadosMACBA
